newsitem.title: VIETNAM: Vietnam to produce arabica coffee, lift output.
newsitem.headline: Vietnam to produce arabica coffee, lift output.

text.p: Vietnam will produce 100,000 tonnes of arabica coffee by 2005 and plans to raise its output of robusta coffee to 300,000 tonnes by 2000, officials said on Tuesday.

Doan Trieu Nhan, vice-chairman of state coffee company Vinacafe, told an Asia coffee conference here that up to 100,000 hectares (247,100 acres) of land in the highlands of the country would be planted with arabica.
"Expansion of arabica coffee in the northern mountainous provinces will contribute to the promotion of socio-economic development in these localities," he said.
Vietnam currently produces only a small amount of arabica coffee.
Robusta accounts for almost all the 240,000 tonnes expected to be exported in the 1996/7 harvest season.
Nhan said the increase in arabica coffee would not affect robusta production.
Ngo The Dan, vice-minister for agriculture, said revenue from coffee exports reached over $400 million last year and Hanoi plans to boost production further.
"Vietnam plans to increase land under cultivation to 250,000 hectares in the year 2000 to reach total coffee production of 300,000 tonnes a year," he said.
